subsection.title: Ratios
subsection.p: A ratioratio is a type of quotient used to compare two numerical quantities.

For example, suppose the ratio of pupils to computers at a local elementary school is 10 to 3. This means that for every 10 pupils in the school there are 3 computers. We often display a ratio as a fraction, like this: \dfrac{\text{Number of pupils}}{\text{Number of computers}}=\dfrac{10}{3}

warning.p: This ratio does not mean that there are exactly 10 pupils and 3 computers at the school. There could be 40 pupils and 12 computers or 200 pupils and 60 computers (or many other combinations) because \dfrac{40}{12}=\dfrac{200}{60}=\dfrac{10}{3}

statement.p: In a survey of 100 of his classmates, Greg found that 68 students supported a strict gun control law, while 32 students did not. What is the ratio of survey respondents who support gun control to those opposed?

solution.p: The ratio of those supporting gun control to those opposed is 68 to 32, or \dfrac{68}{32}. This ratio reduces to \dfrac{17}{8}, or 17 to 8.

warning.p: When we write a ratio, it is important to notice which number is the numerator, and which number is the denominator. When we write "the ratio of a to b" as a fraction, a is the numerator and b is the denominator.

subsection.p: In , we could also compute the ratio of opponents to supporters of the gun control law. In that case, the answer would be \dfrac{32}{68} or \dfrac{8}{17}, the reciprocal of the answer to Example 1.

assemblage.title: Ratio
assemblage.p: A ratio is a type of quotient used to compare two numerical quantities. The ratio of a to b is written \dfrac{a}{b}.

assemblage.title: Look Closer
assemblage.p: A ratio can be expressed as a decimal instead of a common fraction. Because \dfrac{17}{8} is equal to 2.125, we can write the ratio in as 2.125 to 1. We usually express a ratio as a decimal fraction if the numbers being compared are decimal numbers.

statement.p: A small circuit board measures 4.2 centimeters long by 2.4 centimeters wide. What is the ratio of its length to its width?

solution.p: The ratio of length to width is \dfrac{4.2~ \text{cm}}{2.4~ \text{cm}}, or 1.75, as you can verify with your calculator. (Can you express this ratio as a common fraction?)

statement.p: What is a ratio?

answer.p: A type of quotient comparing two quantities

statement.p: When do we express a ratio as a decimal fraction?

answer.p: When the numbers being compared are decimal numbers

subsection.title: Rates

assemblage.title: Rate
assemblage.p: A raterate is a ratio that compares two quantities with different units.

statement.p: Sarah traveled 390 miles on 15 gallons of gas. Express her rate of fuel consumption as a ratio, and then as a rate.

solution.p: As a ratio, Sarah's rate of fuel consumption was \dfrac{390~ \text{miles}}{15~ \text{gallons}}.
We simplify by dividing the denominator into the numerator, to get \dfrac{26~ \text{miles}}{1~ \text{gallon}}, or 26 miles per gallon.

subsection.title: Proportions

assemblage.title: Proportion
assemblage.p: A proportionproportion is a statement that two ratios are equal.

assemblage.title: Look Ahead
Property of Proportions
assemblage.p: We can clear the fractions from a proportion by cross-multiplying. \blert{\text{If}~~\dfrac{a}{b}=\dfrac{c}{d},~~~\text{then}~~~ad=bc.}

statement.p: Solve ~~\dfrac{2.4}{1.5}=\dfrac{8.4}{x}

warning.p: Cross-mutiplying works only for solving proportions! Do not try to use cross-multiplying on other types of equations, or for other operations on fractions. In particular, do not use cross-multiplying when multiplying fractions or adding fractions.

statement.p: What is a rate?

answer.p: A ratio that compares quantities with different units

statement.p: What is a proportion?

answer.p: A statement that two ratios are equal

subsection.title: Proportional Variables
subsection.p: Suppose that grape juice costs 80 cents per quart, and complete the table.

Did you find that the ratio \dfrac{\text{total price}}{\text{number of quarts}}, or price per quart, is the same for each row of the table? This agrees with common sense: The price per quart of grape juice is the same no matter how many quarts you buy.

assemblage.title: Proportional Variables
assemblage.p: Two variables are proportionalproportional variables if their ratio is always the same.

statement.p: One quart of grape juice costs 80 cents. The price of grape juice is proportional to the number of quarts you buy. How much grape juice can you buy for $10.00?

warning.p: When writing a proportion, we must be careful that both ratios have the same units in their numerators, and the same units in their denominators. In the example above, it would not be correct to equate \dfrac{1000}{x} and \dfrac{1}{80}, because the ratios do not have the same units.

subsection.p: For the grape juice example, the ratio \dfrac{\text{total price}}{\text{number of quarts}} was always equal to 80. The number 80 is called the constant of proportionality.

assemblage.title: Look Closer
assemblage.p: If we let P stand for the price of the grape juice and q stand for the number of quarts purchased, we have the equation \begin{aligned} \dfrac{P}{q} \amp = 80\\ \text{or}~~~~P \amp = 80q \end{aligned} The graph of this equation is a straight line that passes through the origin, as shown below.

assemblage.title: Equation for Proportional Variables
assemblage.p: If two variables are proportional, they are related by the equation y=kx where k is the constant of proportionalityconstant of proportionality.

statement.p: What are proportional variables?

answer.p: Variables whose ratio is always the same
